issues.text: Was there any material irregularity in the conduct of the sale and did it cause substantial injury to the debtor?

anchor.surface_text: In short was there any material irregularity in the companyduct of the sale and did it cause substantial injury to the debtor ?

issues.text: Whether Section 32(8) of the State Financial Corporations Act, 1951 attracts the provisions of Order XXI Rule 90 CPC?

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 8  of the Act attracts the Code of Civil Procedure as far as practicable in the realisation of the dues of the Corporation.

issues.text: What is the ambit of appellate power to review discretion exercised by the trial court in confirming the sale?

anchor.surface_text: the ambit of appellate power to review discretion exercised by the trial court  vide Ward v. James

arguments.claim: The sale should be set aside under Order XXI Rule 90 CPC due to material irregularity in the conduct of the sale and substantial injury to the judgment-debtor.

anchor.surface_text: under Order XXI rule 90, C. P. C. Although many points were urged and considerable time was taken in the arguments, attention was principally focussed on one issue which we will mainly deal with... In short was there any material irregularity in the conduct of the sale and did it cause substantial injury to the debtor ?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ng a still higher price it may prove a self-defeating exercise for industrialists will lose faith in the actual sale taking place and may number care

arguments.court_reasoning: Court applied mind to price adequacy multiple times, rejected lower bids previously, considered circumstances like forced sale, litigation risks, bidder presence; no irregularity or unlinked injury.

arguments.claim: Condition No. 3 in the proclamation allows discretion to reject manifestly inadequate bids, and court failed to properly exercise it.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondents counsel Shri Parekh. drew our attention to condition No. 3 in the present proclamation of sale which is as follows The highest bidders for the two lots shall be declared to be the purchasers... Form 29 prescribed in Appendix E to the Code contains condition No. 3 which is in like terms.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: disbursal of the loan. The Dena Bank the second charge holder with companysiderable stakes in the sale was present on the August and September auction

arguments.court_reasoning: Court has duty to satisfy itself on adequacy before confirmation; discretion exercised properly here after pragmatic appraisal.

arguments.claim: Provisions of Order XXI Rule 90 CPC are attracted to the sale proceedings via Section 32(8) of the State Financial Corporations Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 8  of the Act attracts the Code of Civil Procedure as far as practicable in the realisation of the dues of the Corporation. and so it may be right to apply the provisions of Order XXI r. 90.

arguments.claim: Court confirmation of auction sale requires satisfaction on price adequacy relative to market value; no automatic right for highest bidder.

anchor.surface_text: The courts activist obligation to exercise a discretion to make a fair sale out of a court auction and avert a distress sale is underscored by this provision... Unless the Court is satisfied about the adequacy of the price the act of confirmation of the sale would not be a proper exercise of judicial discretion.

arguments.claim: Material irregularity includes failure to apply mind to price reasonableness; requires both irregularity and substantial injury linked to inadequacy.

anchor.surface_text: The expressions material irregularity in the conduct of the sale must be benignantly construed to cover the climax act of the court accepting the highest bid... Here substantial injury without material irregularity is not enough even as material irregularity not linked directly to inadequacy of the price is insufficient.

arguments.claim: Court should not adjourn sales indefinitely for higher price; pragmatic appraisal of factors like value, trends, bidder needs, litigation risks.

anchor.surface_text: What is expected of the judge is not to be a prophet but a pragmatist and merely to make a realistic appraisal of the factors... The court may consider the fair value of the property, the general economic trends the large sum required to be produced by the bidder, the formation of a syndicate, the futility of postponements and the possibility of litigation...

arguments.claim: Executing court exercised conscientious discretion in confirming sale at Rs. 11.5 lakhs given circumstances; no material irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: So viewed, we are satisfied that the district court had exercised a conscientious and lively discretion in concluding the sale at Rs. 11 .5 lakhs... we are satisfied that the District Judge had committed no material irregularity in the conduct of the sale in accepting the highest offer of the appellant on September 3, 1969.

arguments.claim: Rains on September 3 affected bidder attendance and price.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Parekh has levelled a number of criticisms of the court sale which we regret are more captious than substantial... Complaining about the rains in Bombay that day-, i.e. September 3,

arguments.court_reasoning: Captious; valuation treated as tentatively sound absent alternative.

arguments.court_reasoning: Exaggerated; court considered actual bids, trends, risks over hypothetical values.

arguments.claim: Auction purchaser willing to pay full valuation amount of Rs. 17,48,096/- regardless of outcome.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: bid is acceptable companyclude the sale. The companyrt may companysider the fair value of the property, the general economic trends the large sum req

arguments.court_reasoning: Court directs deposit of balance at that price and possession.

arguments.claim: Frequent adjournments self-defeating; deter bidders and undermine court sale credibility.

anchor.surface_text: If court sales are too frequently adjourned with a view to obtaining a still higher price it may prove a self-defeating exercise for industrialists will lose faith in the actual sale taking place... The judgment debtors plea for postponement in the expectation of a higher price in the future may strain the credibility of the court sale itself...

arguments.claim: Presence of JD director at auctions without objection to conduct or request for postponement.

anchor.surface_text: A material circumstance which weakens the first respondents case is that on both the dates-August 28 and September 3 Shri B. Paul director of the judgment debtor company was present it the auction and never voiced any grievance about the conduct of the sale...

arguments.claim: Dena Bank (second charge holder) present at auctions, no objection to sale conduct or price.

anchor.surface_text: The Dena Bank the second charge holder with considerable stakes in the sale was present on the August and September auctions through a senior representative and did not think it necessary to raise any objection regarding the conduct of the sale or the price tendered.

arguments.claim: Adequate bidders present (30-40), including major concerns; judges maximized price.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do the proceedings disclose an unfair under- value on account of the absence of effective bidders or inertness of the Judge. On both occasions there were about 30 or 40 bidders. The judgment debtor. the second charge holder the Indian Oil Corporation and other leading industrial concerns...

holdings.text: Section 32(8) of the Act attracts the Code of Civil Procedure as far as practicable in the realisation of the dues of the Corporation and so it may be right to apply the provisions of Order XXI r. 90.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 8  of the Act attracts the Code of Civil Procedure as far as practicable in the realisation of the dues of the Corporation. and so it may be right to apply the provisions of Order XXI r. 90.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision explicitly applies CPC provisions insofar as practicable to recovery proceedings.

holdings.text: The district court had exercised a conscientious and lively discretion in concluding the sale at Rs. 11.5 lakhs and committed no material irregularity in the conduct of the sale.

anchor.surface_text: So viewed, we are satisfied that the district court had exercised a conscientious and lively discretion in concluding the sale at Rs. 11 .5 lakhs... we are satisfied that the District Judge had committed no material irregularity in the conduct of the sale in accepting the highest offer of the appellant on September 3, 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applied mind to price adequacy over multiple auctions, rejected lower bids, considered forced sale factors, bidder presence, litigation risks, no evidence of irregularity or unlinked injury.

holdings.text: The expressions 'material irregularity in the conduct of the sale' must be benignantly construed to cover the climax act of the court accepting the highest bid; failure to apply its mind to the reasonableness of the price offered may amount to material irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: The expressions material irregularity in the conduct of the sale must be benignantly construed to cover the climax act of the court accepting the highest bid... Therefore failure to apply its mind to this aspect of the conduct of the sale may amount to material irregularity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Order XXI Rule 90 to include judicial act of acceptance as part of sale conduct.

holdings.text: Substantial injury without material irregularity is not enough; material irregularity not linked directly to inadequacy of the price is insufficient; both elements required under Order XXI Rule 90.

anchor.surface_text: Here substantial injury without material irregularity is not enough even as material irregularity not linked directly to inadequacy of the price is insufficient.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict application of two-prong test under Order XXI Rule 90 requiring proof of both irregularity and causally linked injury.

holdings.text: In every case it is the duty of the Court to satisfy itself that having regard to the market value of the property the price offered is reasonable; unless satisfied about adequacy, confirmation is not proper exercise of judicial discretion.

anchor.surface_text: In every case it is the duty of the Court to satisfy itself that having regard to the market value of the property the price offered is unreasonable. Unless the Court is satisfied about the adequacy of the price the act of confirmation of the sale would not be a proper exercise of judicial discretion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Nayaluxmi & Sons requiring judicial satisfaction on price adequacy before confirmation, no automatic right in highest bidder.

holdings.text: What is expected of the judge is not to be a prophet but a pragmatist and merely to make a realistic appraisal of the factors; court may consider fair value, economic trends, bidder requirements, futility of postponements, litigation risks.

anchor.surface_text: What is expected of the judge is not to be a prophet but a pragmatist and merely to make a realistic appraisal of the factors... The court may consider the fair value of the property, the general economic trends the large sum required to be produced by the bidder, the formation of a syndicate, the futility of postponements and the possibility of litigation...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing multiple case-specific factors in exercising discretion without hindsight or indefinite adjournments.

holdings.text: Mere inadequacy of price cannot demolish every court sale.

anchor.surface_text: If the market value was over 17 lakhs, it is unfortunate that a lesser price was fetched. Mere inadequacy of price cannot demolish every court sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Price inadequacy alone insufficient without irregularity and injury under Order XXI Rule 90.

holdings.text: We see no merit in the application to set aside the sale and are constrained to allow the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We see no merit in the application to set aside the sale and are constrained to allow the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative findings on absence of grounds under Order XXI Rule 90.

holdings.text: Nor need we consider the ambit of appellate power to review discretion exercised by the trial court vide Ward v. James since here we are concerned with an order refusing to set aside the sale under Order XXI r. 90.

anchor.surface_text: Nor need we consider the ambit of appellate power to review discretion exercised by the trial court  vide Ward v. James  since here we are concerned with no appeal against the approval of the sale by the executing court but with an order refusing to set aside the sale under Order XXI r. 90,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not arising on facts as challenge under Rule 90, not direct appeal on confirmation.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; no merit in application to set aside the auction sale; appellant (auction purchaser) directed to deposit balance purchase price of Rs. 17,48,096/- (over Rs. 2,75,000/- already paid) within two months for confirmation of sale and possession; Corporation given liberty to withdraw its dues with interest
directions: Appellant to deposit the balance of Rs. 17,48,096/- within two months from today in the District Court, Thana
Upon deposit, appellant to be put in possession of the properties forthwith
Corporation at liberty to withdraw amount to the extent of its dues with up-to-date interest
Parties to bear their own costs throughout
